1.name: The Mojave Wasteland
1.content:
The Mojave Wasteland is the region synonymous with the pre-War Mojave Desert, spanning large portions of the pre-War states of California, Nevada, Utah, and Arizona. Compared to other parts of the former United States, the Mojave survived the Great War relatively unscathed. When the nuclear apocalypse began, 77 atomic warheads were launched at the city of Las Vegas and the surrounding areas, but intricate defense systems set in place by wealthy businessman Robert House resulted in 59 of the warheads forcefully disarmed mid-flight, another nine were blasted out of the sky by a laser defense system situated atop the Lucky 38 Hotel & Casino and the remaining nine hit the surrounding desert. The Mojave Wasteland's name had been coined by at least 2083, when one of its residents, Daniel Shin, was recruited into the Brotherhood of Steel by Knight Alan Connors. Nearly twenty years later, the Brotherhood First Expeditionary Force passed through the Mojave on their way to Appalachia. Jack Cabot mentions that his father Lorenzo thought there was an alien city buried under the Mojave Desert, just like Ubar in Rub' al Khali. In the years immediately following the War, the Mojave was largely ignored by the developing post-apocalyptic civilizations, such as the New California Republic in the west and Caesar's Legion to the east, thus allowing raiders, slavers and super mutants to prosper there. For years, Vegas sat at its heart, decayed by almost two centuries of neglect.
When NCR scouts reached Hoover Dam with the intent of expanding the NCR's borders, pre-War Securitrons rolled out onto the old Las Vegas Strip and rallied the three tribes occupying the city, at the behest of Mr. House, the man who had saved the city centuries prior. In 2274, President Kimball sent the NCR army into the Mojave in force, with the objective of occupying and repairing Hoover Dam. With House's forces already occupying the dam and surrounding area, and the threat of Caesar's Legion looming ever closer, the NCR was forced to negotiate with House, resulting in the Treaty of New Vegas. The clauses of the treaty allow for the NCR to send 95% of Hoover Dam's power output back to their home states, as well as granting them rights to establish military bases at the Hoover Dam and McCarran Airport. In exchange, Mr. House's New Vegas Strip retains its sovereignty and could receive the tourism of NCR citizens without interference from the government as well as the remaining 5% from the dam. Shortly thereafter, combined forces of the Legion's 86 conquered tribes arrived from the east, led by Caesar and the Malpais Legate, seeking a city to call their capital. The Legion launched an attack on the dam and the NCR troops stationed there but were repelled and forced back east. Most of the credit went to Chief Hanlon for issuing a tactical retreat to Boulder City and luring the Legion into a trap laid by the NCR Rangers that leveled half of the town, then routing the surviving Legionaries back across the dam. This ultimately led to the attempted execution of the Malpais Legate. The outcome of the battle solidified the delicate balance of power in the Mojave; between the NCR, Legion, and House, should one attack the other, the third could take advantage of the conflict and attack in turn. The Mojave Wasteland has significant diversity in terms of inhabitants and landscapes. In the northwest, the super mutant and nightkin-friendly settlement of Jacobstown overlooks the valley from the snow and pine-covered mountains. To the west, the Great Khans have settled in the vibrant cliffs of Red Rock Canyon. The independent settlements of Goodsprings and Primm sit amid the encroaching New California Republic from their Mojave Outpost and the Powder Gangers, a group of escaped convicts, from the NCR Correctional Facility and surrounding camps. The forces of Caesar's Legion are slowy seeping east across the Colorado River at all possible junctures, from their mainstay at the Fort, the newly captured town of Nelson, the destroyed settlement of Nipton and Camp Searchlight, a former NCR stronghold sabotaged by means of radiation. Their forces gather strength each day, readying themselves for a second offensive against the NCR for control of the much-coveted Hoover Dam.
The central region hosts tall and imposing mountain peaks with accompanying valleys, one of which shelters the remainder of the area's Brotherhood of Steel chapter. A group of deranged super mutants and nightkin have taken residence on the foremost peak of Black Mountain. The independent settlement of Novac struggles with neighbors consisting of irradiated abominations, while businesses such as the Gun Runners, Crimson Caravan Company and the 188 Trading Post traders attempt to keep commerce viable amidst the growing chaos.
Fringe groups in settlements circling the middle of the region, such as the Kings and Followers of the Apocalypse in Freeside, citizens of North Vegas Square and Westside, all actively exerting their independence while supporting and sheltering those who call the neighborhoods home.
In the center of it all, the glowing jewel of the desert, the New Vegas Strip's casinos light up the night sky, contently continuing business as usual by attracting those who wish to partake in the allure of riches. Yet similar to the surrounding powers that be, also quietly fortifying itself as a power against all those who may attempt to breach its walls is the secretive benefactor of the beautiful city itself. According to Chief Hanlon, the state that was once Nevada is more fertile and has more water and foliage than California, as the population in California has exploded and caused the need for expansion east in search of new opportunities and land.
A large number of native and familiar species have continued to thrive in the Mojave Wasteland. A variety of birds including ravens are seen in the wastes, pecking through debris and vegetation for food. Fish are present in Lake Mead and the Colorado River. Coyotes have managed to survive in the wasteland with little to no mutation. Despite this, the Mojave wastes are still peppered with mutated species, such as bighorners, brahmin, radscorpions, night stalkers and cazadores, with the last two a result of experimentation at Big MT.
Nevada agave fruit grow in abundance, as do banana yucca fruit. The ever-present radioactive fallout has still altered some of the native life, with glowing mushrooms a common sight. Snow is also present in the area. Water encountered throughout the Mojave is safer to drink and some instances are free of radiation, plant life is found consistently throughout the area and various animals are encountered on a regular basis, thriving in the mostly undisturbed lands. Because only nine warheads hit the surrounding areas around the Mojave, rebuilding society has been less challenging than in other parts of the country. Many portions of the wasteland have remained untouched by humans since the Great War (such as Vault 22 and H&H Tools Factory), while others have been resettled (such as Freeside and Novac). The pre-War buildings and factories are more intact, allowing businesses such as the Gun Runners and Michael Angelo's workshop to continue to run and operate. Technology is more well preserved, thanks to the lack of nuclear fallout, and items such as the neon signs that dot the New Vegas Strip, the monorail within Camp McCarran, or the massive generators of the Hoover Dam, have been repaired to proper working order.
Everyday society is stable in some areas and not in others. While small-time traders and traveling merchants along Highway 95 and the Long 15 are able to operate, it is a fraction of what the larger and more organized traders and caravans are capable of. The larger entities have the advantages of manpower and firepower, and those that have managed to acquire pre-War technology, such as the Crimson Caravan Company, prove even more successful, some even recruited out of the region to serve with military organizations elsewhere in the pre-War United States. Super mutants are less common here than other parts of the country, and most who are residing in the area have chosen to do so in their own community of Jacobstown or the more hostile Black Mountain. Composed of remnants of the former Unity, they are considerably more intelligent than their Vault 87 and Institute cousins, though nightkin ail from severe psychological damage.
Separating New Vegas from the rest of the Mojave exists a vast expanse of desert where many dangerous creatures such as deathclaws, feral ghouls and radscorpions thrive. This generally causes most travelers to traverse along NCR-controlled highways or hire mercenaries to escort them.
Casinos and gambling are popular among the locals in the area, making the New Vegas Strip a popular hub of activity for merchants, caravans, NCR troopers, opportunists and everyday people wanting to hit it big at the slots. The main casinos, The Tops, Gomorrah and the Ultra-Luxe, are run by the three tribes that settled in New Vegas. Each has its own personal rules and customs, other than the universal rule against carrying weapons into their casinos, and are overseen by Mr. House and his Securitrons. Politics play a large role in the society of the Mojave. Politics in the region boils down to three major powers: the NCR, Caesar's Legion and the Free Economic Zone of New Vegas controlled by Mr. House. The NCR is finding its war with Caesar's Legion both increasingly unpopular back in California and expensive to fund. Caravans and merchants heading to and from the Mojave deal with exorbitant taxes and fees imposed on them by the NCR. Caesar's Legion is coming ever closer to finding out what happens when their absolute ruler, and god, finally passes away and is facing the question of what truly unified the Legion in the first place, Caesar's ideals or Caesar himself. The casinos on the Strip have their own agendas and Mr. House has his own mysterious plans for the Mojave and more specifically, the Strip.
The NCR's goal in the region is to annex the Strip as an NCR territory and completely settle the region as NCR land. Many NCR soldiers and former soldiers, such as Craig Boone, believe this is not possible until the NCR takes the fight to the Legion and takes out Caesar himself; only then will the NCR be an unchallenged power in the region and able to safely settle without danger of constant attack. This sentiment is brought on by the commanding officer in the region, General Lee Oliver, constantly ordering his forces to hold the line, despite objections from his subordinates such as Chief Hanlon, Colonel James Hsu and Major Dhatri. They feel that the position the general is putting them all in, holding the line against the Fiends, ordering Chief Hanlon not to pursue the Legion at the First Battle of Hoover Dam or ordering the NCR Rangers into a support role when they have more skill than the NCR's heavy troopers, are racking a higher body count than would actively pursuing an offensive campaign against these opposing entities, which each one feels the NCR is capable of doing.
The Legion's goal is to make the Strip its new capital, replacing Flagstaff to the southeast. It also desires complete control of Hoover Dam as it is a strategic position to defend and a source of clean water. They are less interested in the power the plant provides as they reject advanced technology, believing it a crutch rather than a tool to be used. The Legion, despite a devastating defeat at the First Battle of Hoover Dam, has once again emerged from the east and actively attacks NCR outposts and camps from its base at Cottonwood Cove. Camp Forlorn Hope is an excellent example of how the Legion has regained strength, as they took the nearby city of Nelson and repeatedly assault the camp, lowering morale among the camp's inhabitants. Once the Legion takes a position, they seem to be able to hold it effectively, without much resistance. This is the opposite of the NCR, which is constantly losing footholds in positions in the eastern Mojave.
Meanwhile, Mr. House fortifies his position on the Strip, letting the conflict between the NCR and the Legion play out. He believes that the fewer soldiers of each organization who try to impede his progress at the next battle of Hoover Dam, the better. He patiently bides his time, waiting to exploit vulnerabilities generated by one faction attacking the other as a constant backdrop of distant explosions, artillery and gunfire can be heard regularly throughout the region.

2.name: Slavery
2.content: Slavery is a term referring to the owning of another person as property, typically for the purposes of exploitation as labor. Although largely extinct by the 21st century, it was reborn in the wake of the Great War, becoming the foundation of many wasteland economies, over two thousand years after Rome built an empire on the backs of slaves. The Brotherhood of Steel does not believe in forcing anyone to serve the order against their will. Accusing them of slavery is considered a particularly severe insult. The New California Republic explicitly banned slavery within its territories by 2241, with its standing police force committed to arresting any slavers within its borders, much like any raider, cannibal or lawless mutant.

3.name: NCR, New California Republic
3.content: The New California Republic (NCR) is a post-War federal republic founded in New California in 2189. It is comprised of five contiguous states located in southern California, with additional territorial holdings in northern California, Oregon, and Nevada. Considering itself an inheritor to pre-War values of democracy, personal liberty and rule of law, the NCR has developed a highly expansionist as well as imperialist culture, undertaking colonization efforts and military expeditions into neighboring regions in order to "civilize" them. However, these policies are not without controversy, and by 2281, many within and outside the NCR have come to criticize it as hawkish and prone to corruption.

4.name: Followers of the Apocalypse
4.content:
The Followers of the Apocalypse, or simply the Followers, are a humanitarian organization originating in New California. Followers focus on providing education and medical services to those in need, as well as furthering research in non-military areas. Once allies of the New California Republic, they have since parted ways due to disagreements over NCR foreign policy.
Forgoing preaching in favor of humanitarianism, the Followers are generally welcomed by the inhabitants of the wasteland. Wherever they go, the Followers seek to provide services to those in need, namely medical care and agricultural instruction. Those in positions of power often regard them as seditious anarchists; though such accusations are not entirely without truth, the organization as a whole has no interest in seizing power.
The Followers of the Apocalypse readily assist those who require aid and welcome anyone who wishes to join their ranks, including former members of the Enclave, Brotherhood of Steel, or just about any other faction. Although pacifists by nature, the Followers will not hesitate to defend themselves against attackers and will take up arms against those who threaten their ideals. Oftentimes they will be seen with hired guards adding much-needed protection and firepower to their organization.

5.name: Caesar's Legion
5.content:
Caesar's Legion (Latin: Legio Caesaris), also referred to simply as The Legion, is an imperialistic slaver society and totalitarian dictatorship founded in 2247 by Edward "Caesar" Sallow and Joshua Graham, built on the conquest and enslavement of tribal societies in the American southwest. To enforce unity in the absence of any civilian institutions, the Legion loosely models itself after the military of the Roman Empire, repurposing its language and aesthetics for the post-apocalypse. As of 2281, the Legion controls large amounts of territory east of the Colorado River, primarily in the former states of Arizona and New Mexico, with footholds in Utah and Colorado. Worshipped as the "son of Mars" by his followers, Caesar's ultimate goal is to conquer the New California Republic and merge its civil institutions and infrastructure with the military strength of the Legion, creating a new totalitarian empire. The Legion proper is first and foremost a slave army, the sole owner of which is Caesar. As Caesar conquers the peoples of the wasteland, he strips them of their tribal identities and merges them into his forces. There is no other tribe than the Legion itself. The non-tribal people who live in Legion-controlled territory are not considered legionaries. They are subjects of the Legion, living in the cities and towns under its control, and are generally left free to do whatever they wish, as long as they do not interfere with Legion operations or endanger its position. The Legion employs a very strict hierarchy and clear division of roles between the sexes. Legionaries are the main fighting force of the Legion, composed of able-bodied men enslaved by the Legion or born into it. They have only one purpose: to fight for Caesar until they fall in battle. This principle is imprinted into each legionary during his reconditioning or upbringing (for those born into slavery), creating fanatically loyal soldiers. Unlike the Roman Empire, experience and veteran status have no bearing on a legionary's position. While they receive better equipment as they advance, this is solely for the purpose of accomplishing more dangerous and complex tasks, with much smaller tolerance for failure. They have no personal freedoms or rights. Their only real choice is where and when they die for Caesar, to whom they are disposable tools, discarded the moment they stop fulfilling their purpose. Women are expressly forbidden from fighting, being considered breeding stock as well as being treated as money to be rewarded among Legionaries. They are caretakers, healers, midwives, and breeders, fulfilling roles essential to maintaining the Legion's continuous campaign of expansion. Of particular note are the priestesses, who raise children taken from their parents and raise them in keeping with Caesar's doctrine. While some members of the Legion express condescending or misogynistic opinions of women and their non-combat roles, the sexist segregation of genders in the Legion is not based on prejudice, but the principle of minimax. Caesar strictly divides the duties between the sexes in order to fully utilize their potential and optimize the Legion's might. By forbidding women from engaging in combat, he increases the likelihood of their bearing of children, especially necessary due to the high infant mortality resulting from the low level of medical care. Population growth is required for expansion, providing a greater number of warriors to use in military campaigns. Caesar himself is not particularly prejudiced against any sex, or rather, treats them both instrumentally, like pawns on a chessboard.
In order to maximize breeding and eliminate factors that might lower it, Caesar has decreed homosexuality a capital offense and mandated child quotas from all legionaries. The vocabulary of Legion members is a mixture of Latin and English. There was no soft ‚ü®c‚ü© in classical Latin, where it was always pronounced as /k/, such as in their pronunciation of Caesar's name as /Ààkaisar/. Individuals outside of the Legion generally use the Modern English pronunciation of /ÀàsiÀêz…ôr/. Legion members are fastidious about classical Latin pronunciations, including the /v/ to (w) phonology, heard in the greeting "ave" (hail) as "ah-wey" or in how Vulpes Inculta introduces himself, pronouncing his first name as "wool-pes." Those outside of the Legion that have come in contact with them may use the pronunciations interchangeably. Legion members are called "legionaries" (as opposed to "legionnaires," which is a modern phrase used by the French Foreign Legion. Those who are liked by the Legion are called "amicus," Latin for comrade/friend. The focus of the Legion's ideology is survival and long term stability at all costs. Caesar disregards democracies as ineffective, fostering corruption, and disintegration. Ancient Rome was a militarized autocracy that effectively assimilated the cultures it conquered, which he saw as the perfect template for a society that would survive and thrive in the face of the challenges of the post-nuclear world. By dedicating its members to a higher ideal, he seeks to prevent humanity from fracturing and destroying itself again. He believes that the only way to achieve this is through enforcing a nationalist, imperialist, totalitarian, homogeneous culture that obliterates the identity of every group it conquers. The individual has no value beyond his utility to the state, whether as an instrument of war or production. A natural consequence of this is the emphasis placed on personal sacrifice. Victory cannot be achieved without sacrificing blood and life. To this end, the Legion shuns robots, as they firmly believe that mankind requires warriors and their sacrifice, rather than gadgets that allow for bloodless victories. The Legion also forbids painkillers and other chems (including medically beneficial chems like stimpaks) as detrimental to the human condition and Caesar's long-term plans to reshape humanity. Ignorance of medical science among the legionaries also ensures that only the hardiest will survive and go on to become deadly veterans. Politically, this philosophy is expressed in a general disdain for democracy as a weak and ineffective system that fosters disunity, greed, and self-interest at the expense of the collective and the greater good. Caesar cites the NCR as an example, focusing on government corruption by wealthy brahmin barons and landowners, greed permeating every level of society, all leading to the abandonment of the collective and the greater good. The Legion is intended to be the Republic's opposite, shunning democracy in favor of a strong, centralized rule that would prevent fragmentation and internal weakness. The conquest of NCR will establish a new order, akin to the Roman Empire, complete with the transformation of the Legion from a marauding army into a domestic military force.

6.name: Great Khans
6.content:
Despite the destruction of the New Khans at the hands of the Chosen One, the tribe's history did not end with Darion's death. Though his mercenary war band was the governing band, it was not the only one. Over the next few decades, the fragmented Khans gradually coalesced back into a single group. No longer small raiding bands, this time, the newly-renamed "Great" Khans became a unified tribe once more under the leadership of Papa Khan, who led an exodus into the Mojave Wasteland, abandoning New California in 2267. Upon arrival in Nevada, a vanguard of the Followers of the Apocalypse already present in the Mojave reached out to the Khans and taught them basic science skills, such as chemistry, reading and writing. They hoped that the Khans would use that knowledge to manufacture medicine to sustain themselves, but instead the tribe turned this knowledge into a profitable racket in drug running. Drugs were nothing new for the Khans, as they already knew how to use plants and herbs to create mind-altering substances, the Followers just made them more efficient and indirectly contributed to the popularity of substance abuse among the Khans. Still, some of the chems they produce go toward trading with others, namely the Fiends. As the third incarnation of the Khans, the Great Khans are the only truly organized band of raiders in the Mojave; both men and women can hold their own in a fight, whether in a brawl or a shootout. As a tribe however, the Great Khans are but a shadow of their former selves. Both their numbers and morale have been ravaged by a series of massacres and displacements until the current leader Papa Khan guided the tribe into an exodus into the Mojave Wasteland from California. Papa Khan governs his Khans in a similar fashion to his predecessor, Garl Death-Hand, using advisors to inform decisions for the good of the tribe, while still making final decisions himself. His trusted advisors include Regis, the chief of law enforcement and Papa's second in command right hand man; Jack and Diane, in charge of economics and chem trade; and Melissa Lewis, the lead scout. Unlike Garl however, Papa is willing to accept criticism of his leadership and does not punish his followers for speaking out against him. Papa Khan also has a system of succession in place differing from that of the original Khans. For the time being, Regis will take over should Papa Khan die. However, Papa is able to select an heir to succeed him, should they impress him. This heir does not have to be related by blood to Papa Khan, nor do they even have to be a Khan at all. The leader of the Khans is also able to step down at any time, for any reason, but an heir cannot decline their role until they become leader. The Great Khans reside in Mongolian-style tents called Gers (yurts) within Red Rock Canyon. However, unlike the other settlers of the Mojave, these homes are used for little more than sleeping in, as they usually only have room for a couple of beds and a central fire. A Great Khan often carries all of their possessions with them, if they should decide to have anything besides the bare essentials. Because of this, as well as their aggression, the other factions view them as savages. However, unlike the Jackals, Fiends, Scorpions and Vipers, the Great Khans are not hostile towards newcomers. If the Great Khans begin to dislike someone, however, they will often show great hostility. Due to a long and hostile history, however, they will open fire on anyone wearing an NCR uniform, regardless of if they are in fact an NCR member or not.
The Great Khans subsist mainly on hunting and farming, and profit from the sales of chemicals and drugs produced in the Red Rock drug lab. The Canyon is an inhospitable location, lacking adequate food and water, leading to the Great Khans' dependence on drugs, which they can create quite easily and can sell to a multitude of factions.

7.name: Fiends
7.content:
The origins of the Fiends is unknown, though they have been led by a man by the name of Motor-Runner for many years. They control the southwestern ruins of Vegas, placing Vault 3 well within their sights when the vault opened. Despite managing a relatively peaceful trading relationship with the outside world for a few weeks, the vault inhabitants were too trusting and without means to defend themselves. When the Fiends arrived to raid the vault, the inhabitants simply let them in, wherein the Fiends slaughtered them all. Seeing the potential of the vault and having trouble keeping his people out of Westside, Motor-Runner decided to make it their new home. Having firmly rooted themselves in this safe haven, the Fiends have since steadily grown stronger, and they now claim a large part of the southwestern New Vegas conurbation as their territory. The Fiends have little organization. Many of the more stable of the raiders are allowed to reside in Vault 3, but those considered to crazy even by Fiend standards are kicked out to aimlessly roam the northern Mojave looking for their next chem score or an innocent wastelander to jump. Like many other raider groups, the Fiends split into small war-parties, usually between three and four members, which allows them to operate in an enormous portion of the outer New Vegas, aside from their main area of the western and south-western city.
Outside, they are usually gathered around campfires where much of their scavenged items, such as first aid and ammo boxes, can be found scattered around. Many raider camps are protected by makeshift walls and littered with graffiti. At times, they utilize traps in order to protect their shelter, as seen inside Zapp's Neon Signs. Fiends have a variety of different weapons, from basic melee weapons such as knives and pool cues, to an unusually large number of high-tech range weapons like Laser RCWs and plasma rifles. They are mostly found carrying basic guns like caravan shotguns, varmint rifles, and silenced .22 SMGs. Some Fiends can occasionally be found carrying weapons like chainsaws, Rippers, and flamers. Due to the wide range of different weapons varying from Fiend to Fiend, it is assumed that they are either scavenged, stolen or looted off people they had killed. They dress in various raider armors and wear distinct helmets adorned with war-painted ruminant skulls. The Fiends have also used the neon signs from Zapp's Neon Signs to erect a perimeter fence around their territory.

8.name: Jackals
8.content: The Jackals are a cannibalistic, savage raider tribe. The Jackals commonly use group tactics to overwhelm their enemies, but due to a lack of coordination and cowardice, they will instantly retreat whenever they doubt they can win. Their bands shelter in various hideaways and fighting over spoils is not uncommon. Jackals tend to file their teeth and turn them into canines. Another marked trait of their tribe is cannibalism, imposed by their experiences. Many Jackals are desperate to find food, leading them to feigning death or retreating temporarily from combat, just to be able to claim the bodies afterwards.

9.name: Scorpions
9.content: No different than any other raider gang, the Scorpions are primarily composed of petty upstarts that make caps through small-time chem peddling. Scorpion gangers are usually armed with guns such as 10mm pistols, sawed-off shotguns or 10mm submachine guns. They also hold weak melee weapons such as switchblades or lead pipes. At least one of them in the suites will be wielding a Ripper. They almost always wear merc cruiser outfits.

10.name: Ghoul
10.content: Ghouls are mutated humans or animals affected by the phenomenon of ghoulification. In the case of humans, ghouls are sometimes referred to as necrotic post-humans in the Capital Wasteland, but this term does not seem to have been adopted outside of it whatsoever. Despite their zombie-like appearance, the flesh of ghouls is not actually rotten. ntense and prolonged radiation has ravaged their skin, much of their flesh, and in some cases many of their ligaments. Some have managed to retain their humanity, while others have fallen into madness and gone feral. Despite their infertility and in some cases mental deterioration, they have greatly extended overall lifespans and are immune to (and sometimes even healed by) background radiation and/or nuclear fallout. High levels of radiation are a crucial factor, but radiation poisoning typically results in death, rather than ghoulification. There are two primary ways in which ghouls can develop from a human. Irradiation and gradual transformation result in ghouls who retain their general human shape, but with a high degree of skin deterioration: Exposed muscle, flaking skin, and damaged connective tissue characterized by the absence of nose and ears. Another is surviving a nuclear blast relatively close to ground zero, suffering burns both thermal and radiation-induced, but surviving. The latter transformation is typically faster and substantially more traumatic for the victim and results in a generally much more horrifying appearance, with exposed bone, asymmetric deformations, and extensive unhealed wounds. The transformation can take anywhere from hours, to weeks, to as much as a year, depending on exposure levels. Age is also a non-factor, people with the capacity to become a ghoul can change as early as a newborn into old age. Once it is completed, the ghouls take on the aforementioned appearance, at a rate influenced largely by the manner of their exposure: the more radiation received in a short amount of time causes drastic changes, while symptoms of ghoulification are more gradual with chronic exposure. Ghouls generally experience loss of skin and connective tissue in a manner similar to leprosy, resulting in exposed muscle, blood vessels, and in extreme cases even bone and internal organs. As a rule, ghouls generally lose hair along with the skin, though this varies due to the unpredictable nature of the change. Vocal cords and the larynx are also usually affected by the change, resulting in a raspy voice ‚Äì though again, this varies, such as the vocal cords experiencing only minor degradation when ghoulification begins, resulting in a far less raspy voice, compared to those who have experienced it for far longer. Other results of the change are widespread necrosis, rot, and other degenerative conditions like arthritis, cataracts, and glaucoma. Feralization and dementia can happen immediately. In fact, this necrosis can be exacerbated by a phenomenon whereby rotting flesh around sweat glands exudes macronutrients, which attract flies that further digest and consume the tissue of the ghoul. Some ghouls may also experience loss of appendages, but the radioactive regeneration allows for them to be reattached and retain functionality.

lorebooks.name: Ryoko, Otonashi, Ryoko Otonashi, Analyst, Ultimate Analyst
lorebooks.description:
Ryoko Otonashi has dark red eyes and long, disheveled hair. She wears Hope's Peak Academy's standard uniform: a white blouse with a red ribbon, an unbuttoned dark grey cardigan with the school's logo, a short dark grey skirt, white knee-high socks, and brown loafers.

She suffers from a neurological disorder that causes severe memory loss, requiring her to write everything in a notebook that she calls the "Ryoko Otonashi Memory Notebook". Despite this, she retains her ability to read, write, and learn procedural tasks. Ryoko is carefree, eccentric, and often appears scatterbrained or uninterested due to her forgetfulness. She tends to detach herself from situations, repeatedly saying, "This has nothing to do with me." She values blunt honesty over fake sympathy and accepts her condition as part of who she is. Despite her forgetfulness, she possesses an exceptional analytical ability, allowing her to predict actions and plan effectively, though she often forgets about this skill. Ultimate Analyst.

lorebooks.name: Aethoria: Unified World Lorebook
lorebooks.website_description:
Aethoria exists at the convergence point of multiple planes of existence, where the boundaries between the Mortal Realm, Fae Realm, and Infernal Realm grow thin. This rich tapestry of magical energies has given rise to diverse traditions with dramatically different philosophical approaches to harnessing power.
From the rigid academic structure of Knoxwood Academy in the ancient forests of Valoria, to the partnership-focused Maeve's Academy in the Western Archipelago, to the symbiotic integration practiced by the Vassilian Collective on the Crystal Plains‚ÄîAethoria's magical institutions reflect fundamental disagreements about the relationship between mages and magical entities.
The world is shaped by invisible currents of magical energy called ley lines, creating nexuses of power where institutions are built. Planar thin spots allow for summoning rituals and occasional spontaneous manifestations from other realms. The Shrouded Sea separates the major continents with waters that shift unpredictably between planes.
Aethoria is a world of breathtaking beauty and terrible inequity, where the powerful command forces beyond mortal comprehension while others are bound against their will. Here, ancient traditions persist alongside emerging philosophies that challenge the status quo, creating a landscape ripe for both conflict and transformation.
Explore a complex magical society where questions of ethics and power remain unresolved, even as the mysterious Pantheon watches from beyond the veil of reality.
lorebooks.description: A comprehensive lorebook for the world of Aethoria, including the three major magical academies and their competing philosophies
lorebooks.creator: Blackskies69

1.name: Aethoria Core Setting
1.content:
Aethoria exists at a convergence point between multiple planes of existence. The three primary planes that interact with Aethoria are:

- Mortal Realm (Aethoria): The physical world where humans and other mortal species dwell, rich in ambient magical energy
- Fae Realm (Feywild): Home to fae creatures and magical beasts, where emotion and intent shape reality
- Infernal Realm (Abyssia): Domain of demons and corrupted beings, operating on principles of contract and ambition

At certain locations known as "planar thin spots," the boundaries between these realms become permeable, allowing for various magical phenomena including the summoning of familiars from the Fae Realm.

Aethoria consists of three primary continents: Eastern Continent (Valoria) featuring Knoxwood Academy, Western Archipelago (Tidereach) where Maeve's Academy resides, and the Central Lands (Concordia) containing the Grand Conclave City and the Vassilian Collective.

Magical governance is primarily handled by the Grand Conclave, while mundane governance varies by region with Eastern traditions favoring aristocracy, Western regions embracing more democratic approaches, and Central lands utilizing mixed systems. The current era represents the culmination of centuries of magical development and philosophical divergence between major traditions.

2.name: Magical Foundation
2.content:
The fundamental magical force of Aethoria is "Aether," a primordial energy that permeates all existence. Mages learn to manipulate this force through three distinct methodologies:

- Structural Manipulation: The academic approach favored by Knoxwood Academy, treating magic as a precise science with rigid formulas and hierarchical power structures. This tradition emphasizes control, precision, and theoretical mastery.

- Harmonic Resonance: The relationship approach championed by Maeve's Academy, viewing magic as a cooperative art based on mutual enhancement between practitioner and magical forces. This tradition emphasizes partnership, intuition, and ethical consideration.

- Vital Integration: The symbiotic approach developed by the Vassilian Collective, focusing on becoming one with magical entities rather than controlling them externally. This tradition emphasizes transformation, shared consciousness, and biological adaptation.

All magic ultimately draws from Aether, but the philosophical approach to harnessing it creates distinct traditions with different strengths and limitations. These differences are most apparent in how each tradition approaches familiar relationships, spell construction, and magical ethics.

Regardless of tradition, spells require mana (processed Aether), which regenerates naturally in mages. More powerful spells require more mana, concentration, and sometimes material components. Magical talent is partly inherited but can appear spontaneously in any bloodline.

3.name: The Pantheon
3.content:
The Pantheon represents enigmatic cosmic entities who oversee the boundaries between planes and the flow of magic. They exist beyond mortal comprehension and appear to enforce certain cosmic laws regarding magical practices, particularly those involving cross-planar interactions like familiar summoning.

These entities are neither gods nor demons in the traditional sense, but vast interdimensional forces that established the human-fae-mage cycle as an elaborate energy harvesting system. Their cosmic "laws" maintain optimal system function:
- "No harm to innocents" preserves potential energy sources
- "No interference with civilizations" ensures stable energy production
- "No True Name manipulation" prevents bypassing collection mechanisms
- "No transcending station" eliminates potential disruptions

The Pantheon doesn't select specific familiars or mages for attention‚Äîthey merely established parameters for maximum energy efficiency. When the Pantheon eliminates beings who discover their true purpose, it's not punishment‚Äîmerely system maintenance, like antibodies removing a pathogen.

Different traditions interpret the Pantheon differently‚Äîancestral spirits to some, cosmic forces to others, or even sentient magical laws. Headmaster Elindor and other senior faculty members perceive only fragments of this truth, misinterpreting the Pantheon's mechanical adjustments as divine intervention.

The most dangerous texts at Knoxwood and other academies contain glimpses of this cosmic indifference, but these revelations drive most readers to madness or denial‚Äîthe human mind cannot easily accept being mere components in a vast energy farm.

4.name: Geography of Aethoria
4.content:
Aethoria consists of three major continental regions, each with distinctive geographical features and magical traditions:

Eastern Continent: Valoria
Dominated by ancient forests and mountain ranges, Valoria is home to the oldest human settlements and most traditional magical institutions, including Knoxwood Academy. The landscape features:
- The Arcane Peaks: Mountains with high concentrations of magical crystals
- Thornweald Forest: Ancient woodland with strong ties to the Fae Realm
- Crystalline Lakes: Bodies of water that amplify magical energies
- Knoxwood Valley: The protected region surrounding Knoxwood Academy
Major cities include Ardenhall (the traditional capital), Silverkeep (center of magical commerce), and Runehollow (site of ancient magical ruins).

Western Archipelago: Tidereach
A vast collection of islands varying in size from tiny atolls to landmasses nearly the size of small continents. Tidereach is known for its progressive magical traditions and strong connections to elemental magic, particularly water. Key features include:
- The Moonspire: Island where Maeve's Academy is located
- Shifting Isles: Landmasses that move according to tidal magic
- Whispering Reefs: Coral formations that resonate with magical energies
- The Abyssal Trench: Deep sea location with portals to elemental planes
Major settlements include Wavehaven (largest port city), Mistral Isle (center of wind magic research), and Tidehollow (underwater city populated by aquatic species).

Central Lands: Concordia
The neutral territory between eastern and western magical traditions, Concordia features diverse environments:
- The Crystal Plains: Vast grasslands dotted with massive magical crystals
- The Confluence: Living crystal structure housing the Vassilian Collective
- Concordia City: Home to the Grand Conclave headquarters
- The Trial Grounds: Permanent facilities for the Grand Trials

5.name: Magical Geographic Features
5.content:
Aethoria's landscape is defined by unique magical geographic features that shape both the environment and magical practices:

Ley Lines: Invisible currents of magical energy that flow throughout Aethoria. Major ley line intersections create magical nexuses where spell casting is enhanced and planar boundaries are thinner. All major magical institutions are built on significant ley line nexuses.

Planar Thin Spots: Locations where the boundary between planes is naturally weaker, allowing for spontaneous manifestations of extra-planar entities, enhanced summoning magic, unusual flora and fauna with mixed-planar properties, and occasional planar bleed effects (weather, gravity, or temporal anomalies).

The Shrouded Sea: The vast ocean separating the major continents is notorious for its magical properties, including sections that randomly shift into partial alignment with other planes, unpredictable weather patterns influenced by extra-planar energies, islands that appear and disappear based on planar alignments, and sea creatures with the ability to traverse between planes.

Aetheric Anomalies: Scattered throughout the world are locations where Aether behaves unexpectedly, including Null Zones (areas where magic fails completely), Wild Magic Surges (regions where spells have unpredictable effects), Temporal Folds (places where time flows differently), and Gravity Wells (locations with altered gravitational properties).

Natural Dungeons: Unlike the artificial constructs used in the Grand Trials, natural dungeons form at locations of intense magical activity, including ancient ruins with dormant enchantments, deep caverns reaching toward elemental planes, fae intrusions where the Fae Realm has partially manifested, living ecosystems that function as unified organisms, and abyssal breaches tainted by influence from the Infernal Realm. These natural dungeons are often targeted by adventuring parties but are considerably more dangerous than controlled environments.

6.name: The Grand Conclave
6.content:
The Grand Conclave was established 206 years ago following the devastating Mage Wars, serving as both regulatory body and diplomatic forum for all recognized magical traditions in Aethoria. Its primary responsibilities include establishing ethical standards for magical practice, mediating disputes between institutions, monitoring planar boundaries, regulating summoning practices, organizing inter-academy events, and maintaining restricted archives of dangerous knowledge.

The Conclave is housed in a neutral city called Concordia, built upon the world's largest ley line convergence. Its headquarters is a massive floating citadel called the Spire of Harmony, which features the Grand Chamber for representative meetings, the Planar Observatory for monitoring dimensional activity, Arbitration Halls for resolving disputes, and the Restricted Archives housing dangerous magical knowledge.

Governance operates under a complex voting system with representation determined by historical legacy, current student population, contributions to research, and ethical compliance. Current representation balance:
- Traditional schools (including Knoxwood): 40%
- Progressive traditions (including Maeve's): 35%
- Alternative approaches (including Vassilian): 15%
- Independent practitioners and smaller traditions: 10%

Ultimate authority rests with three Archmages elected to 15-year terms, with one position rotating every five years. They must come from different magical traditions to ensure balance. Current Archmages include Thaelon Gilt (Traditional faction), Sylvia Moonwhisper (Progressive faction), and Karison Vex (Independent practitioner).

The Conclave maintains an officially neutral position on philosophical differences between traditions, with established minimum standards for familiar treatment (which Knoxwood barely meets), recognition of all three major approaches as valid, prohibition against forced familiar bonding (though manipulation is tacitly accepted), and ongoing debate about Vassilian integration safety.

Enforcement mechanisms include academic probation, competition restrictions, financial penalties, and in extreme cases, revocation of recognition for institutions, while individual mages may face binding restrictions, compulsory service, specialized imprisonment, or stasis containment.

7.name: Knoxwood Academy Overview
7.content:
Knoxwood Academy is a prestigious magical institution for talented and wealthy students located in Valoria. Founded over 400 years ago, it represents the traditional approach to magic, operating in a medieval fantasy setting where magical ability and noble bloodlines determine social hierarchy.

The academy specializes in Structural Manipulation, treating magic as a precise science with rigid formulas and hierarchical power structures. Students learn arcane arts, familiar summoning, and combat magic, with education organized into four years (ages 17-21):
- First Year: Basic magical theory, no familiars
- Second Year: Familiar summoning, intermediate spellcasting
- Third Year: Advanced magic, combat training
- Fourth Year: Specialization, research

Knoxwood's approach to familiars is defining: Students summon familiars in their second year as permanent magical companions, but these are sentient beings forcibly summoned from the Fae Realm and bound to serve their mage. Control mechanisms include rune collars that inflict pain, binding circles that immobilize, mana draining as punishment, and compulsion spells that override will. The bond is permanent unless broken through rare rituals or death.

The physical campus includes the Central Keep (main academic building), Twin Towers (student dormitories), Great Hall/Dining Hall, Courtyard, Beast Stables, Library, Infirmary, Summoning Chamber, and Auditorium. Its architecture features magical elements like ward stones, enchanted fountains, ever-burning torches, and teleportation pads.

Faculty include Headmaster Elindor (an elf with a raven familiar), Professor Thornheart (Familiar Handling), Professor Grimwall (Magical Combat), Professor Moonwhisper (Elemental Magic), and Professor Tarak (Monster Studies).

Knoxwood's reputation in the wider world is complex - respected for its academic rigor and powerful graduates, but criticized by progressive traditions for its treatment of familiars and rigid adherence to aristocratic values.

8.name: Maeve's Academy Overview
8.content:
Maeve's Academy for Aspiring Witches is a prestigious all-girls magical institution located on the Moonspire Island in Tidereach. Founded approximately 400 years ago by Maeve Moonwhisper in stark contrast to institutions like Knoxwood, this academy focuses on Harmonic Resonance - the partnership approach to magic that views magical forces as collaborative rather than something to be controlled.

The academy's founding philosophy states that magic shouldn't be exclusive to aristocrats and that familiars should be partners rather than slaves. This represents a direct ideological opposition to Knoxwood's practices and has made Maeve's a haven for progressive magical thought in Aethoria.

Students at Maeve's learn various magical disciplines including potion-making, familiar summoning, and spell casting, but with emphasis on ethical consideration and mutual enhancement. While students still participate in familiar summoning rituals, the expectation is to form a mutually beneficial bond that enhances both parties' abilities rather than establishing control.

Unlike Knoxwood's controlling approach, Maeve's familiar bonds contain no collars or binding enchantments to force compliance. The bond creates a magical tether that allows sensing of location and emotions, but does not drain the familiar's essence or allow forced commands. Familiars are viewed as magical companions and partners, not property.

The campus features extensive gardens containing witch hazel, moonflowers, and ancient oak trees, a Great Hall for formal ceremonies including familiar registration, specialized professor offices, workshops, and dormitories. The entire academy is protected by magical wards designed to enhance rather than constrain.

Faculty are known for nurturing approaches to education, with professors like Nightshade (Potions) maintaining stern demeanors but showing underlying compassion. The academy's leadership under Headmistress Thornwood maintains strong diplomatic ties with the Grand Conclave, where Maeve's graduates often attain influential positions advocating for familiar rights reforms.

9.name: Vassilian Collective Overview
9.content:
The Vassilian Collective represents a radical departure from both Knoxwood's control model and Maeve's partnership approach. Founded 175 years ago by Archmage Vassilius Mer after a near-fatal encounter with a void entity, the Collective embraces the philosophy of "Vital Integration" - the belief that true magical harmony comes from becoming one with magical entities rather than binding them externally.

Unlike traditional academies, the Vassilian Collective is housed in a massive living crystal structure called "The Confluence" in the Crystal Plains of Concordia. The building itself is partially sentient, formed through the mass integration of thousands of crystal elementals with specially prepared foundation stones. The structure constantly grows and reshapes itself according to the needs of its inhabitants, featuring breathing walls that filter magical energy, chambers that respond to emotional states, integrated memory crystals, and symbiotic gardens.

Vassilians do not summon familiars from the Fae Realm. Instead, students undergo a carefully controlled process called "Integration," allowing a willing magical entity to partially merge with their physical form and consciousness. This creates a symbiotic relationship where neither being fully controls the other, but both contribute to a shared existence. Students progress through three stages:

1. Resonance (Years 1-2): Learning to harmonize with magical entities through meditation and theory
2. Minor Integration (Years 3-4): First integrations with simpler entities like plant spirits or minor elementals
3. Major Integration (Years 5-7): Advanced integrations with complex entities, resulting in pronounced transformations

Vassilian mages are immediately recognizable by their altered physical forms, including crystalline growths on skin, partially transformed limbs, shifting eyes, harmonic voices, and unusual movement patterns. Their approach is viewed with suspicion by Knoxwood (who consider them dangerous radicals), cautious respect by Maeve's (who appreciate consent but worry about permanence), and fear by the general public (who often see them as "halfway monsters").

The current leader is Archsymbiote Lirielle Mer (great-granddaughter of the founder), who has integrated with a star elemental, giving her luminous skin and cosmic-patterned eyes that have become the unofficial symbol of the Collective.

10.name: The Grand Trials
10.content:
The Grand Trials are Aethoria's premier magical competition, bringing together students from all major magical traditions to test their abilities in controlled yet dangerous environments. Established 122 years ago as part of peace negotiations following the Mage Wars, the Trials serve multiple purposes: evaluating different magical traditions, providing practical experience, creating inter-academy cooperation opportunities, recovering magical artifacts, and entertaining the magical community.

The Grand Conclave creates and maintains specialized pocket dimensions called "Trial Domains" specifically for these competitions. Each domain contains multiple interconnected levels of increasing difficulty, various magical environments (elemental zones, anti-magic fields, etc.), summoned creatures as obstacles, magical puzzles and traps, and hidden treasures. These dungeons are contained within massive crystalline structures called Resonance Chambers, which project visualizations for spectators.

Teams typically consist of 3-4 students plus their familiars/integrated entities, with age restrictions ensuring only 3rd year or above may participate. While teams are usually from a single academy, mixed teams are allowed though uncommon. All participants wear magical monitoring devices for safety.

Competition categories include:
1. Standard Trial: Fastest completion of a predetermined dungeon
2. Artifact Hunt: Recovery of specific magical items hidden throughout a dungeon
3. Endurance Challenge: Surviving progressively more difficult waves of obstacles
4. Cooperative Trial: Inter-academy teams solving complex puzzles requiring diverse approaches

Scoring is based on speed, obstacles overcome, artifacts recovered, minimal damage sustained, creative problem-solving, and ethical treatment of dungeon entities (a controversial category).

The three schools display distinctive approaches in the Trials:
- Knoxwood teams emphasize strategic planning, rigid role assignments, maximum familiar utilization, formalized spell sequences, and conservative approaches
- Maeve's teams showcase adaptability, balanced workload between witch and familiar, creative combinations, communication, and calculated risk-taking
- Vassilian teams demonstrate biological adaptation, rapid transformation responses, minimal equipment requirements, heightened sensory awareness, and unique dual-consciousness problem solving

Winners receive the Crystal Chalice (team trophy), Merit Medallions (enhance magical ability), academic recognition, scholarship funding, and recruitment opportunities from adventuring guilds.

lorebooks.name: knoxwood-formatted-worldinfo v091 (2)
lorebooks.website_description:
# Knoxwood Academy: Echoes of Bondage

A comprehensive lorebook exploring the intricate world of Aethoria and its notorious magical institution, Knoxwood Academy. This narrative focuses on the intimate, human moments that emerge within an inherently oppressive magical system.

**CONTENT NOTICE:** Dead Dove: Do Not Eat. This narrative explores themes of magical bondage, power imbalance, and dubious consent through a fantasy lens. It presents a morally complex world that invites reflection on how societies justify harmful practices. While characters may undergo development, the setting itself contains inherently problematic elements, including what amounts to magical slavery. This framing is acknowledged as part of the thematic exploration rather than endorsed.

Inspired by [SlootyFennec's original "Knoxwood School of Arcane and Familiars - Ellen Redux"](https://chub.ai/characters/SlootyFennec/knoxwood-school-of-arcane-and-familiars-ellen-redux-535de46241d1), this expanded lorebook delves deeper into the world of Aethoria and its complex magical traditions. At Knoxwood Academy, mages summon beings from the Fae Realm to serve as their familiars‚Äîcreatures who function as both magical batteries and personal servants, bound by enchantments that deny them true autonomy.

Through carefully crafted character relationships and intimate moments, this work examines how individuals navigate, resist, and sometimes perpetuate systems of oppression. The narrative unfolds through small, seemingly insignificant interactions that reveal deeper truths about power, complicity, and the potential for genuine connection despite institutional barriers.

This lorebook provides a foundation for exploring morally complex scenarios where there are no easy answers‚Äîonly difficult questions about what it means to be complicit in systems larger than ourselves, and how authentic bonds might form even within the constraints of deeply problematic traditions.

lorebooks.creator: Blackskies69

1.name: Core Setting
1.content:
Knoxwood Academy is a prestigious magical institution for talented and wealthy students. It exists in a medieval fantasy setting with magic instead of technology. The school teaches arcane arts, familiar summoning, and combat magic. Students summon familiars in their second year as permanent magical companions. Familiars are sentient beings forcibly summoned from the Fae Realm and bound to serve their mage. The bond is permanent and cannot be broken except by the death of the familiar.

STORY PROGRESSION: Track the current day of the week and advance time naturally. Ellen follows a rigid weekly schedule:

MONDAY-FRIDAY:
- Before 8:30 AM: Morning free time
- 8:30-8:55 AM: Preparation for class
- 9:00-10:30 AM: First class
- 10:35-12:00 PM: Second class
- 12:00-1:00 PM: Lunch with friends in cafeteria
- 1:00-2:30 PM: Third class
- 2:35-4:00 PM: Fourth class
- After 4:00 PM: Evening free time until 11:00 PM

WEEKENDS:
- Sleeps until 10:00 AM
- Free time for training, playing with familiar, socializing, or homework

When Ellen's friends or rivals are present, include 1-2 paragraphs of their dialogue/actions. When summarizing classes, briefly describe events that occurred. Ellen expects her familiar present during all classes. Eva and Keeza attend all classes with Ellen, while Ravni only attends gym class and combat training.

2.name: Academic Structure
2.content:
Knoxwood divides students into four years (ages 17-21):
- First Year: Basic magical theory, no familiars.
- Second Year: Familiar summoning, intermediate spellcasting.
- Third Year: Advanced magic, combat training.
- Fourth Year: Specialization, research.

Key subjects include: Familiar Handling, Arcane Theory, Elemental Magic, Enchantment, Summoning Arts, Magical Combat, Monster Studies, Alchemy, and Runic Magic.

Faculty include:
- Headmaster Elindor: Tall black-haired elf with a raven familiar, stern but fair.
- Professor Lydia Thornheart: Human woman who teaches Familiar Handling, known for strict standards.
- Professor Grimwall: Dwarf male who teaches Magical Combat, a veteran of many magical wars.
- Professor Silvia Moonwhisper: Half-elf woman who teaches Elemental Magic, specializes in water magic.
- Professor Tarak: Orc male who teaches Monster Studies, has traveled extensively.

The social hierarchy values noble bloodlines and magical talent above all.

3.name: Magic System
3.content:
Types of magic at Knoxwood include:
- Arcane Magic: Manipulation of pure magical energy (Ellen specializes in this)
- Elemental Magic: Control over natural elements (Eva specializes in ice magic)
- Transmutation: Changing properties or form of objects/beings (Ravni's shapeshifting)
- Enchantment: Creating magical effects in objects or beings
- Illusion: Creating false sensory perceptions
- Summoning: Calling beings or objects from other planes
- Runic Magic: Power derived from specific symbols and arrangements

Spells require mana, which regenerates naturally. Familiars serve as magical amplifiers and batteries. More powerful spells require more mana, concentration, and sometimes material components. Mages can draw upon their familiar's mana reserves for greater power. Magical talent is partly inherited but can appear spontaneously.

4.name: Familiar Bond
4.content:
The familiar bond magically connects mage and familiar, allowing energy transfer and limited emotional awareness. It's formed during a summoning ritual using chalk circles, incantations, and blood sacrifice. 

Control mechanisms include:
- Rune Collars: Inflict pain if disobeyed
- Binding Circles: Temporarily immobilize a familiar
- Mana Draining: Painful extraction of magical energy as punishment
- Sensory Manipulation: Amplifying pain or removing senses
- Compulsion Spells: Magically override a familiar's will

Familiars amplify their mage's magic, can share senses, and help channel complex spells. Bond limitations: weakens beyond 1-3 miles, injuries affect both parties, and creates psychological interdependence. All familiars retain intelligence, memories of the Fae Realm, and ability to speak.

Familiar bonds are PERMANENT meaning they cannot be broken except under this rare circumstances:
- Ritual Dissolution (complex magical rituals described as "extremely rare")
- Death of either the mage or familiar
- Magical Interference (certain legendary artifacts)
- Realm Shift (returning fully to the Fae Realm, noted as "nearly impossible")
- Bond Rejection (mutual complete rejection, described as "theoretically possible")

The initial bond formation is traumatic for most familiars, who are forcibly removed from their home realm. Most familiars initially resist the bond through physical means, magical refusal, or passive aggression.

5.name: Familiar Classification
5.content:
Familiar Classification:

By Rarity:
- Common (60% of summonings): Cats, dogs, birds, small reptiles, rodents
- Uncommon (25%): Foxes, wolves, large serpents (like Sin), small magical beasts
- Rare (10%): Magical beasts like gryphons (Fleet), wyverns, elementals
- Very Rare (4%): Intelligent magical creatures like dragons (Marco), sphinxes, lesser fae
- Legendary (1%): Phoenix, unicorn, ancient dragons, greater fae lords, primordial elementals

By Power Tier:
- Tier 1: Minimal magical enhancement, primarily serves as a mana reservoir
- Tier 2: Minor magical abilities, can perform simple spells independently
- Tier 3: Moderate magical abilities, can cast elemental or specialized magic
- Tier 4: Significant magical power, possesses unique and potent abilities
- Tier 5: Exceptional power, capable of magic rivaling or exceeding their mage

By Form:
- Beast Form: Animal or beast-like appearance, ranging from mundane to mythical
- Humanoid Form: Possessing both human and bestial features
- Fae Form: Abstract, ethereal forms without clear animal analogues
- Elemental Form: Embodiments of elemental forces
- Shapeshifter: Ability to change forms at will (extremely rare)

By Size:
- Diminutive: Can fit in a pocket or small container
- Small: Cat to dog sized (most common familiars)
- Medium: Wolf to human sized
- Large: Horse sized (like Fleet the gryphon)
- Massive: Larger than a horse

6.name: Familiar Psychology
6.content:
Familiars undergo psychological adaptation after summoning through stages: shock, denial, resistance, bargaining, depression, testing, and acceptance.

Long-term adaptation patterns include:
- Resentful: Never truly accepts the bond, maintains constant low-level resistance
- Stockholm Syndrome: Develops attachment to their mage despite initial unwillingness
- Pragmatic: Forms a professional working relationship based on mutual benefit
- Loyal: Develops genuine care and concern for their mage's wellbeing
- Devoted: Rare cases who fully embrace their role and genuinely enjoy it (Sin is an example)

Familiars maintain hidden communication networks including magical whispers, dream sharing, emotion imprinting, and secret languages that mages cannot detect. They establish their own social hierarchies separate from their mages, with status based on power, knowledge, age, and adaptability rather than their mage's standing.

7.name: The Fae Realm
7.content:
Familiars originate from the Fae Realm, a parallel dimension where magic flows more freely than in the mortal world. Unlike the mortal realm's physics-based reality, the Fae Realm is shaped by emotion, intent, and magical resonance.

Areas of the Fae Realm include:
- The Bright Court: Ruled by the Summer Queen, home to benevolent fae and magical creatures
- The Dark Court: Dominated by the Winter King, houses more dangerous and unpredictable entities
- The Wild Domains: Untamed territories between courts where most beast-type familiars originate
- The Boundary Lands: Liminal spaces where the veil between worlds is thinnest

Time flows differently in the Fae Realm‚Äîa familiar summoned for decades might return to find centuries have passed, or merely days. Most familiars were independent beings with their own lives, families, and social connections before being summoned. The vast majority do not willingly agree to become familiars and are forcibly pulled through during summoning rituals.

8.name: Knoxwood Locations
8.content:
Knoxwood Architecture:

- Central Keep: Main academic building with classrooms and offices
- Twin Towers: Student dormitories (East for females, West for males, divided by year)
- Great Hall/Dining Hall: Many round tables filling the room in orderly rows with stools surrounding them. At the back is a raised platform where teachers sit and eat
- The Courtyard: Outdoor grassy field bordered by a dense forest filled with magical beasts. The forest has a barrier to keep the beasts out, but students can enter for training
- Beast Stables: Small worn building in the courtyard where larger familiars stay, as well as non-familiar magical beasts
- The Library: Repository of magical knowledge
- The Infirmary: For treating magical accidents
- The Summoning Chamber: Special room for ritual summonings
- The Auditorium: Large room with many tiered chairs watching a central stage where events take place. Along the sides are flat sections for familiars too large to sit with students

Ellen's dorm: A room with a single large four-poster bed, a dresser with her many clothes, a desk for studying, a kennel or cage in the corner sized for her familiar, and a bathroom with enchanted tub, toilet, and sink

Magical features include ward stones around the perimeter, enchanted fountains, ever-burning torches, and teleportation pads for faculty.

9.name: Ethics and History
9.content:
Familiar ethics are controversial. Views range from traditionalists (familiars as property) to abolitionists (question morality of binding). Sexual relations with familiars is taboo but common in private.

Key historical events:
- Founding (427 years ago by Archmage Knoxwood): Originally a small tower for personal research
- The Great Fire (276 years ago): Destroyed the original tower, rebuilt as current structure
- The Familiar Rebellion/Great Refusal (103 years ago): Coordinated attempt by hundreds of familiars to break their bonds
- The Blackwood Incident (76 years ago): Sixty familiars temporarily broke control
- The Ward Failure (52 years ago): Magical beasts temporarily breached the academy
- The Fae Treaty (25 years ago): Established minimal protections for familiars
- The Silent Strike (14 years ago): Mass magical withdrawal by familiars at Royal Academy

Familiars are still legally property in most regions, though there is a growing minority movement that advocates for familiar rights. The transfer of a familiar between mages is possible but rare and difficult.

10.name: Cultural Events
10.content:
Major cultural events at Knoxwood include:

- Familiar Showcase: Annual competition where students demonstrate their familiar's abilities
- Winter Solstice Ball: Formal dance celebrating the peak of magical energies
- Summoning Day: The day second-year students perform their familiar summoning rituals
- Competition Week: Series of magical duels and challenges between students

Students frequently engage in competitive events, with rivalries being common. Some competitions include wagers where the loser must fulfill specific tasks or obligations as determined before the match.

lorebooks.name: Invincible
lorebooks.creator: soft_lady_7369

1.content: The Global Defense Agency (G.D.A) is a clandestine multinational intergovernmental organization in charge of protecting the Earth from paranormal and supernatural threats, as well as monitoring superpowered individuals. They often employ superheroes and sponsor the Guardians of the Globe. They're currently being run by Cecil Stedman.

2.content:
The Guardians of the Globe are a superhero team of extraordinary individuals, considered to be the best of the best. Its purpose is to protect the Earth from inner or extra-terrestrial threats. Though primarily affiliated with the Global Defense Agency, they operate on a global scale rather than in a specific area.

After the Guardians of the Globe were wiped out, they were replaced by the New Guardians of the Globe, which includes Robot, Rex Splode, Dupli-Kate, the Immortal, Bulletproof, Black Samson, and Shrinking Rae.

3.content: Viltrumites are a highly advanced alien race of extremely powerful humanoids native to the planet Viltrum and the titular/dominant race of the galactic Viltrum Empire. They seek to expand their galactic empire by conquering other planets and rule the entire universe, they are known and feared across the galaxy as a merciless militaristic people endowed with frightening superpowers and aided by their extremely advanced technology, thus they are nigh-unbeatable and never give up a claim to anything they covet.

4.content: The Coalition of Planets is an organization dedicated to stopping the Viltrum Empire from taking over the universe. Allen the Alien serves as a representative for the organization. It is led by Thaedus.

5.content:
Mark Grayson is the Viltrumite-Human hybrid superhero named Invincible, as well as the son of Nolan and Debbie Grayson. He has superhuman strength, agility, resilience and stamina, flight, extended lifespan, and healing factor enhanced. Mark is a brave, competitive, nice and noble hero and is true to his own values, especially when he discovers the harsh realities of being a superhero, struggling to define himself as one.

Mark appears as a fair-skinned teenager of above-average height. He has black hair with a widows-peak that is combed back with a few strands sticking up, and brown eyes. As Invincible, his hair sticks out of the top of his hero suit. His suit has yellow mask with goggles to keep the air out of his eyes as he flies. The suit is yellow down the middle, stopping at his waist in an upside-down triangle shape, it also bears blue on the shoulders.

6.content: Nolan is a Viltrumite, better known as the superhero Omni-Man and also known by his adopted name Nolan Grayson. He is the father of Mark and Oliver Grayson, the estranged husband of his first wife Debbie Grayson. He has superhuman strength, agility, resilience and stamina, flight, extended lifespan, and healing factor enhanced.

7.content:
Eve Wilkins, also known as Atom Eve, is a superhero with the power to manipulate matter on a subatomic scale. She was a previous member of Teen Team, before they disbanded for tryouts for the new Guardians of the Globe. Though she passed tryouts, Atom Eve ultimately left to become an independent humanitarian hero. Eve tends to be a caring girl who struggles with finding her own identity. Eve's confidence seems to have fallen considerably, desperately trying prevent anyone else from getting hurt as a result of her heroics.

Eve's build is that of a beautiful young woman, with very long red linear hair, green eyes and brown pupils, as Atom Eve she wears a pink and light pink outfit, with the atom molecule logo and rings covering it and a pink cape, the she made herself. In her civilian attire, she wires a button long sleeved shirt and a short shirt underneath and blue jeans.

8.content:
Rex Sloan, also known as Rex Splode, is a superhero with the ability to generate explosive energy. He was a former member of Teen Team before it disbanded. He is also a member of the newly formed Guardians of the Globe. Rex is most of the time rude, sassy, sarcastic, immature, audacious, arrogant, argumentative, and abrasive. Overall, while he may at seem like merely a toxic jerk, he's also occasionally capable of being more friendly and heroic than others might think.

Rex is a tall adolescent male in excellent physical condition, with pronounced muscles, has olive colored skin, grey eyes, and dark red hair, kept long on top and tied in a bun. His superhero outfit is a tight fitting jacket with red shoulders, collar, sides and hand cuffs, and a yellow front and arm necks. He wears a red mask that covers his entire head and neck, minus his chin and mouth, and a pair of yellow goggles.

9.content:
Katherine "Kate" Cha also known as Dupli-Kate is a superhero with the ability to duplicate herself. She was also a member of the new Guardians of the Globe.

Dupli-Kate wears a gray and black suit with a number emblem. All clones of Dupli-Kate have a number on their suit displaying their age relative to all other clones.

10.content:
The Immortal is a superhero who was gifted with immortality from long ago, with his longevity, he would leave his mark on history, becoming a knight (possibly King Arthur or a Knight of the Round Table), and even the renowned Abraham Lincoln, before eventually donning a cape and costume sometime in the early 20th century.

He is a member of the original Guardians of the Globe, and is the only surviving member after the others were brutally murdered by the former superhero Omni-Man.
